div.p: TITHES No Gospell Ordinance, Nor ever Instituted of God for the Maintenance of A Gospell Ministry; But ended, With the Leviticall Preisthood, and Abollished by the Offering Æ²p of Christ Proved by Scripture.
As also, The Levitticall and Scripturall Tythers With the Vnscripturall Tythers Compared; And the Moderation of the one, and Insatiable avarice of the other Manifested.
Printd in the yeare 1680.

THat which I have to R â¢ commend to thee in thy perusall of this little Booke, is Candor in Reading and d â¢ ligence in searching the Scriptures I have opened Remember the Title of Nobillity wherewith the Apostle dignified the B â¢ r â¢ ans Actes 17.11. vers. They (saith he) were more Noble then those in Thessalonica, in that they received the word with all readiness of minde & searched the Scriptures daylie whether those things were soâ And the same I recommend to thee and that thou Judge nothing before the time.

For I am not Æ²nse â¢ sible but that a worke of this Nature will be obnoxiouse to Censure, But what truth (though never so manifest) is not vnpleaseing to some or other, as this in all likelyhood will be too few or none but A Covetouse and decimateing Clergie, whose persons I hate not (though I thus speake,) But in my heart retaine a fitting and due respect for them as men; well knowing they have a portion of Gods heavenly gift, and divine Grace, aswell as I and others; (did they not abuse it, and keep it in bondage, by averice and lucre, (the maine prop â¢ nd Pillar of their Calling and Function, which are the things I vtterly deny and testifie against. And if there b â¢ of them that hold it their duty to speake that which they think to be truth impartially as the worke of their Ministry, (though not vnhired and well payd) let them not think amisse of others who think the same no â¢ less their dutie by the generall Office of Christianity to speak truth more Impartially; freely, and without payments.
Therefore try all things, and hould fast that which is good which, as it will adde to thy knowledge in the things of God so it will answer the end and designe of

div.head: Tythes noe Gospell Ordinance &c.
div.p: THe Lord Almighty, the God of Abraham and of his seed, and grand Proprietor of the Land of Canan, pursuant to his promise made to his faithfull Servant in the plain of M â¢ reah, Saying Vnto thy seed will I give this Land Genesis 12.7. After the Expiration of about six hundred and fifty y â¢ ares brought Abrahams seed into possession of the Land of promise, and made Eleaven Tribes of twelve freeholders, reserving only Tythes holy to himself as Moses witnesseth Lev: 27.30. in these words And all the Tith of the Land, whether of the seed of the land or of the fruite of the trees, it is the Lords, it is holy unto the Lord. And vers the 32 concerning the Tith of the Heard, and of the Flock, even whatsoever passeth vnder the Rodd, the tenth shall be holy vnto the Lord. And Deut: 14.22. Thou shalt truly tith all the encrease of thy seed that the feild bringeth forth yeare by yeare &c.

This was tithing by divine Institution & by Gods Ordinance, But (allwayes to be remembred) vnder the Ministration of the old Covenant, the Mosaick law (which made nothing perfect) and the Leviticall Pristhood (which could not continue by reason of Death) and this being a changeable Preisthood there is a necessitie also of a change of the law, as saith the Apostle Heb: 7.12. But it being the Grand objection of the Clergie of this Age (and many others upon their account) That forasmuch as God once Ordained and Commanded the payment of tith, it still remains in force as a perpetuall binding law to all Generations; It was once law â¢ ull (say they) and never vnlawfull; And therefore tithes as properly and vndenyablie belonges to the Clergie of this Age, and these Nations now, as ever it did to the Levitecall Preisthood vnder the first Covenant.

And vpon this ground I my selfe have severall times (in times
past) been impleaded in the Consistory Court (so called) for desireing the payment of tith, and know not how soone I may be so againe for the same cause, which CAUSE, I doe preferr before all earthly Relations or considerations whatsoever. I have therefore (to the end I may give some account of my Testimonie herein, and in order to the satisfaction of some that have desired the same.

First. Dilligently examined the paying and receiving Tith vnder the Mosaicke law, and duly enquired into the grounds and reasons thereof, together with other needfull circumstances as well relateing to the time and place, the persons concerned in the paying and receiveing of it. And whether the Command of God which was given to the Israellites vnder the old Covenant be of force and binding vpon beleivers vnder the new Covenant Yea or nay.
Secondly. I have compared the tithing of the Clergie of this age and Generation, with the Leviticall tithing (vpon which they ground their practice) and shewed wherein it differeth.

And Thirdly, have shewed how burdensome and oppressive the tything of the Clergie of this age is, beyond what was the practice of the Levites in their dayes; and inconsistant with the rules of Common equity and principles of pure Reason.
First. As to the first, I referrence to the Leviticall tything, I have considered the extent of Gods Command wherevpon the payment of tythes was grounded.
Secondly. The extent of Gods donation or graunt whereon the takeing or receiveing tyth was also grounded.
Thirdly. The equall Just and reasonable consideration wherevpon both the Command and graunt were grounded.

Of these in their purposed order, & first of the first Namely of the extent of Gods Command, wherevpon the payment of tithes was grounded, and of that, first as it related to the tyme when and how long, Secondly, the place where, Thirdly the
Persons whom concerned in the payment thereof.

First, I say as it hath relation to the time when, and that I finde to be only during the Continuance of the first and old Covenant, the first and changable Preisthood and the first Tabernacle, which Tabernacle was a figure for the time then present, and the service whereof as the Apostle witnesseth Heh: 9.9. 10th, Stood only in meats and drinks and divers washings and Carnall Ordinances w â¢ ich were imposed till the time of Reformation &c. And dureing that time, vntill the Change of that Preisthood (which could not continue by reason of death) And vntill the perfection was obtained by the bringing in of a better hope which by the law could not be obtained (for the law made nothing perfect but the bringing in of a better hope did) Heb 7. v. 19. And vntill the appearance of that everlasting and vnchangable High-Preist Christ Iesus the Righteous, who to put away Sinne by the Sacrifice of himselfe offered himselfe once for all, and by that one offering perfected forever those that are Sanctified. I say before and vntill the appearance of this High-Preist and the offering of this Sacrifice, the Command for tithing as well as for offering Sacrifices vpon the Altar) was in force and noe longer.

And this as to point of time was the vtmost extent of that Command! For the same that put an end to the Service of the first Tabernacle, and the work of the first Preist-hood & tooke it cleane away, did also abolish and take away the wages that was appointed for that worke.

Secondly, As the Command for tithing relates to placeâª I doe not find either by writing or tradition amongst the Jews that it extended to any other place then to the Land of Canaan only, and it is very manifest by Lev: 27. vers the 30. and 32. and Deut: 14. v, 22. and other Scriptures That the vtmost extent of the Command was circumscribed within the Inheritance of the twelve Tribes.

Thirdly, The extent of the Command as it relates to persons
concerned in paying tith, I find to be limitted to the Children of Israell, the Jewish nationall Church only, and not to concerne any other Nation, Church or people in the world. For this is still the Phrase of Scripture concerning Gods Laws, Commands & Institutions, Namely, The Lord spake vnto Moses saying, speake vnto the Children of Israell thus or thus &c. He doth not bid Moses give this Command to all the Children of men, to be observed in all ages, in all places and by all Nations Jews and Gentles; Nay, if this could be made appeare by those those that Challenge tithes from Gentiles Churches, the Controversie would soone be ended.

Secondly, And in the next place (haveing before considered of the extent of Gods Command as it relates to time, place and person) I offer to consideration the extent of Gods Donation or graunt wherevpon the lawfull takeing & receiveing tithes was also grounded; And that is to be considered with like circumstances; which as to time and Place is limitted as the former. And if any man whatsoever can produce the warrant of Divine Authoritie, for asking, taking or receiving (much less enforceing) tithes in any other Place then in the land of Canaan, of any other People then of the Israelites then let me beare the blame and Shame for disobeying.

And this I further observe, That God reserving tithes from the Eleaven tribes, Graunted it over to the tribe of Levie not absolutely but conditionally; allowing them a Competancy for themselves and enjoyneing them by the same Authority to admitte of severall Sharers with them of each two yeares tith, the owner was to eate a Share his Sonn and Daughter, his man Servant and Maid Servant as appears in Devt: 12.17. and eighteenth verses. And in every third yeares tith, the Stranger Fatherless and Widdow were to be admitted Sharers as appeares Deut: 14.28.29. verses. And Deut: 26 12.13. verses. So that by the afore mentioned Scriptures it's plainely manifest, That the owner and his Family the Stranger Fatherless and Widowes are by divine
appointment as truly vested in the right of tythes, as any Levite whatsoever.

The nex thing remarkable is, The just and equall consideration wherevpon both the Command for paying and the graunt or warrant for receiveing tythes was grounded. Where by the way it is to be noted, That the seed of Abraham (on whom the land of Canaan was entailed by promise above five hundred yeares before) was by this time Multiplyed into twelve numerouse tribes, all which were travelling to possesse the land. And every Tribe in point of Common interrest was equally intituled to an Inheritance, vntill God in his Divine wisdom seperated the tribe of Levie for the Service of himselfe to give attendance at the tabernacle, and to Minister before him in the Sanctuary; And to the end they might the better Attend his service, he promised himselfe to be their portion and Inheritance; and therevpon by a perpetuall Statute law deprived them of an Inheritance in the land Numbers 18. vers the 20. And the Lord spake unto Aron, Thou shalt have noe Inheritance in their Land, neither shalt thou have any parte among them, I am thy part and thine Inheritance among the Children of Israell &c. And in further compensation of their loss & recompence of their Service, he graunted them tythes for an Inheritance as vers 21. And behould I have given the Children of Levie all the tenth in Israell for an Inheritance, for their service which they serve, even the service of the Tabernacle of the Congregation &c.

By all which, and severall other Scriptures it appeares That both the Command for paying & the warrant for receiving tythes was founded upon a most rationall, Just, and equal consideration; both as it related to the advantage of the payer and the losse of the receiver; For though the Levites did receive a yearely tenth of the encrease, they lost the Inheritance of A twelfth for ever. And therefore well might the eleaven tribes aford to pay their tenthes and be noe loosers; it being but a reasonable exchange or purchase to give their Brethren a yearely
tenth, for the free Inheritance of a twelfth for ever.

Secondly, If tythes be due by the the Law of God, and payable and receiveable vnder the second Covenant, as vnder the first (as the Clergie do affirme they are) Then certainely they must allow that they are to be applied to the same vses for which they first were Instituted; and that was not only to the Levites but to the Stranger Fatherlesse and Widdow.

Thirdly, among the Jewes Tythes were payable to the Levites who did the Common service of the Tabernacle and Temple, and not to the Sonnes of Aron the Preists, for they had only a tenth part of the tyth, And therefore they that claime tyth by the Law of Moses, must prove (if they can) how the payment of tythes to Preists now doth duly answer the payment of tythes To Levites then who were no Preists, nor were to touch or medle with the holy office least they dyed Numb: 4 15. to vers 19.

Fourthly, Tythes vnder the first Covenant were the Levites wages for the Ceremoniall work they were appointed to do about the first Tab â¢ rnacle Numb: 18. vers 21.31, which work is now abollished; So then the wages therefore of that Ceremoniall work must with all be abolished as being also Ceremoniall.

Fifthly, That tythes was Ceremoniall is vndeniablie manifest, they not being given but on this expresse condition, viz (first) to offer an heave Offering of them to the Lord, Numb: 18. from v. 21.8. to 31. Then necessarily it follows, That who over by that Law brings Tythes into the Gospell (which is the Ministration of the new Covenant) vnavoydably bringes in there withall A Sacrifice, and an Altar without which tythes were by that Law vnsanctified and poluted vers 32, and so makes void the one offering which was the Substance, Christ Iesus who was typified and shadowed forth, both by Tabernacle Sacrifice and Altar.

Sixthly, If tythes be due by the Law of God to Ministers vnder the Gospell, as they were to the Levites vnder the Leviticall Preisthood Then are such Ministers by the same Law deprived
Ipso, facto, of all pretences of tymes to any temporall inheritance numb: 18: vers 20. And by the same Law, those that pay them tythe may as Justly claime a title of Inheritance in their free lands as they may claime an Annuall tenth of the others increase.

Seventhly, Among the Jews noe Rigorouse outward Law or penalty of tr â¢ ble damage or Imprisonment was appointed to recover tythes by, nor was the Magistrate authorized or warranted by the Law of God to force the payment of them, much less to Imprison for refusall or neglect, but he that did not pay robed God and by him alone was to be punished.

Eightly, When the levites Preist-hood was changed by the Comeing of Christ Iesus, the law for tything was also changed, as the Apostle witn â¢ sseth Heb. 7. vers 12. for (saith hee) the Preist-hood being changed, there is made a necessitie of a Change also of the law. And this was the Iudgment also of the Primitive Church, And if the most learned Rabbies in the Nation can prove the contrary, let them come forth & shew if they be able, when, where and by whom tithes were received or payd for above three hundred yeares after Christs Assention.

The next thing that falls vnder consideration is, how inconsistant and disagreeable the Practice of tything of the Clergie of this Generation is with the Law of God vpon which they say it is grounded.

And first (as I have formerly hinted) Gods Ordinance for tything related only to the land of Canaan, which was confirmed by the Practice of the Jews and the Contrary whereof hath never yet appeared; nor have I ever found that dureing their captivity they payd or received Tythes in Babylon or Cal â¢â¢ ca, before Christs time, neither have they since, in Holland, Jermany, Poland, or elswhere that I can learne. And if this be so, then certainly for Christians to hold vp tythes, when Jews have layd them down, seemes very obsurd preposterouse and vaine.

Secondly, The levites graunt or warrant for the takeing ty â¢ hes
by Gods appointment, Extended only to their Brethren the Israelites, Gods only peculier people and Christ; not to
â¢ dolaters, Forrainers or fals-Worshipers. Of any other Nation or Religion, nor to poor laborers, fatherlesse or Widows of their own Generations. But only such as had possessions of Free Inheritance.

But the Clergie of this Generation not contented (as the Levites were) to have their tything limitted by Gods allowance (vnto those only of the same Religion and Profession with themselves without distinction, or definition of Nation or Religion, They Extend their claime to all the Decimall gaine within their Quarters, and all the Inhabitants they their finde (whether English, or Jrish, Protestants or Papists true or falce worshippers it matters not to them, or whether they are Rich or poor, Fatherless or Widowes bound or Free) If they are Possest of oug â¢ t that yeildes Increase, whether Corne or Garden, Cowes or Sheepe, Piggs, Geese or Henns or Egges) whether little or much, all is by th â¢ m accounted lyable to Decimation; And moreover many Poor laboring men that have not any liveing tythable thinge where of to pay, But get their Bread by hard and toylesome labour have Impositions taxed on them by the Clergie under the name of hand Money Apron Money and the like, which in my Iudgment hath more Affinitie with Pharoah Task-Masters then leviticall Tythes; For to exact a Tything rate upon Poor laborers & such as have noe tithable substance in the world whereof to pay â¢ ? what is this lesse then to make Bricke when Straw is taken away.

Thirdly, the levites had noe power to seize their Brethrens Corne before it was devided (nor was it their Practice by what appeares in Scripture. But Patiently attended vntill it was sett out and delivered both unto them & their copartners Deut: 14. vers 28. But the Clergie of this age (contrary to their example) either by themselves or Prockters many times have entred Mens Corne feilds and other Places with Clubes and Staves, vi et armis, takeing away what they pleased in their Masters names by force and violence, as bad or worse then those Sinfull Sonnes
of Elie 1. Sam, 2.12. who by their abusive Servants Seized their pretended Preistly due by force, whereby the offering of the Lord became abhored & truly this very practice makes many as much to abhor their message, for the avarice of its Ministers, and that about that thing which they pretend to be the offerring of the Lord.

Fourthly, The Levites had the tythes made over to them partly in compensation of their inheritance in land, And Partly in consideration of their service and Attendance at the Tabernacle (as before is shewed) Numb: 18. verses 23.24. wherewith they were contented and Murmered not, although their shares of land was given from them, and they to vndergoe a perpetuall law of deprivation. Neither was there any Tribe or family bound to pay them tyth, but such as were obliged by a valuable consideration so to do, (as being vested according to proportion more or less) in part of their inheritance of land; So that he that payd his tyth by Gods appointment bad this fourefold benefit or advantage by it. First By the Paying of the Annuall tenth of his Increase, he had the Free-Simple of a Twelfth to him and his for ever. Secondly, By the payment of tyth the Stranger Fatherless and Widow were provided for, which otherwise must have been relieved at his Cost. Thirdly He had the Priviledge for himselfe and family to â¢ ate a parte thereof Deut: 12.18. And fourthly he had the benefit of the Levites service about the Tabernacle and Temple in assisting about the Sacrifice as 2. Cron; 35.11. and other services pertaining therevnto.

But what advantage, priviledge or benefit, have the people of this age by paying Tythes? will the Clergie of this Generation allow the Priviledge to their Maintainers and admit of so many Sharers with them as the Levites did, and were bound to do by Gods Commandments? What Clergin an will be content to release his claime to Lands and Tennements, and suffer his temporall Inheritance to be devided amongst those of whom he Claimeth Tythes? And do the Clergie now admit the Poor the
Fatherlesse and Widowes (who had as good Right by Gods Command as any Levite had) to Share with them in Tythes?

Or do they not rather multiplie the Poor by their oppressions? and make the Fatherless & Widows cry to the Lord against them? And if the owner should but give a part of his Tythes to relieve the Poor and needy (as by Gods law the Israllites was bound to do) would not the Parish Preist be ready to devoure him for so doing, and never leave pursueing him vntill he had him to prison for it? Surely if this be so (as multiplied instances have confirmed it is) This is far differrent from the Practice of the Levites, and rather suites with the Practice of those erronious Prophets which the Lord complaines of Micah: 3. vers 5. who made his people err, who did bite with the teeth and cry peace, and be that put not into their Mouthes they prepared warr against him.

Fifthly, I find that the Lord by the Mouth of Moses in Deut: 12.17. and 18 verses (to every person concerned in paying tyth) Speaketh on this wise saying, Thou mayest not eate within thy gates, the tyth of thy Corne or of thy Wine, or of thy Oyle &c. But vers 18. Thou must eat them before the Lord thy God, in the place which the Lord thy God shall Chuse; Thou and thy Sonn and thy Daughter, thy man Servant and thy maid Servant, and the Levite that is within thy gates &c. And againe in Deut: 14.22 23 verses it is thus written, Thou shalt truly tith all the Increase of thy seed which thy feild bringeth forth yeare by yeare, And thou shalt eat before the Lord thy God in the place which he shall chuse to place his name there, the Tyth of thy Corne, and o â¢ thy Wyne, and of thy Oyle &c. And verses 24.25.26. And if the way be too long for thee &. Or if the place be too farr from thee &c. Then thou shalt turne it into money &c. And thou shalt bestowe that money &c. For Oxen or for Sheep, for wine or for strong drink, or whatsoever thy soule desireth, and thou shalt eat there before the Lord thy God, THOU AND THY HOUSEHOULD. And vers 27. and the Levite that is within thy Gates thou shalt not forsake him &c. From which foresited Scriptures, these naturall Inferrenecs do vndenyably flow. viz.
First, That as the owner of the tith was bound by Gods Command to divide it from the Rest, So was hee only by Gods appointment the Cheife disposer of it.
Secondly, As the owner was the Cheife disposer, so was it in his free and Arbitrary Choise (in some Cases) whether he would pay it in Kinde or not.
Thirdly, And if he pay it not in kinde, he was only intrusted with the selling of it, or to turne it into money at his own valluation.

Fourthly, When he had sould it or turned it into money it was at his free and voluntary Choise in what provision he would bestow that Money in, whether Oxen Sheep Wine or Strong drink, or whatsoever his soule desired.
Fifthly, Howsoever he pay it whether in kinde or value both he, his Children, and servants were strictly and indispenceably bound to eat a part thereof.
Sixthly, It had b â¢ en as manifest a breach of Gods Command if he and his household had not eaten of it, as if he had denyed to sett it out or pay it.

Seaventhly, And lastly as the owner and his househould were to eate a part, so was the Levite, by the same Command to be a partner with them. And this was the manner of tithing every Two yeares together, But in the Third yeares tything the owner had no such strict Command to eat, yet he was still the Cheife disposer of it, and was to lay it up within his gates, and thither the Levite the stranger the Fatherlesse and Widow were to Come and every one to eate and be satisfied, as may appeare verses 28. and 29.

But the practice of the Clergie, and people of this age is so manifestly differrent here from, that I need not multiply words to sett it forth; for the Clergie now a dayes require the Husbandman to pay his tythes in Kinde, or else compound and pay them money for it (not owneing or allowing that the husbandman himselfe (or any of his, hath right to any part of it, And if he
do not pay the vtmost shilling or shillings worth, then frequently he is in pleaded for the same, and made to pay it by force or suffer for it.
And here me thinks arises a very weighty case of conscience which I propose to the Clergie to resolve.

If it be a sinfull thing (as they affirme it is) for a man to pay noe tyth, since the payment of it was once enjoynde by Gods Command? Whether st is not as sinfull for a man to part with all his tyth, since God hath Commanded, That both he and his househould should eat a part thereof.

Secondly, If there be no dispensation for me and my freindes called Quakers (being but few in a Countrey) to pay noe tythes because God did Command it by Moses to be payd? who shall absolve the whole Nations for paying all their tythes, so directly contrary to Gods Command as I have shewed? from Deut: 12.17.78. verses

Thirdly If the seers have been so Quick-sighted and piously watchfull over the flock that they would not suffer one of a thousand to Err on the one hand by paying noe tyth; have not such been horribly blinded and darkned by Averice, who have caused the whole Nations to sinn on the other hand by parting with all their tythes?

In the next place I observe that the Levites were the Twelfth Tribe in Israell to whom being Added the Stranger fatheless and Widow, could not in likelyhood but make up a full tenth Part of the whole Nation, so that the Eleaven Tribes paying a yearly tenth of their Increase, a tenth part of their people w â¢ re thereby maintained and that very plentifully too; as may appeare at large. 2. Chro: 31.7.8.9.10. verses. Where the Cheif Preist declared to the King, they had enough to eat and left plenty, and that which remaineth (said hee) is this great store &c.

But the Clergie of these last tymes and of this age (though I must confesse the more is the Pitty) are too many more then are good (Yet) I beleive are scarce the hundred part of the People of
these Nations; who neither admiting Fatherless or Widows Poor or Rich (as the Levits did) to be partakers with them, can make a shift to devoure the tenth of our Increase, and yet are never well contented neither. For albeit they allwayes were possest of tythes in kinde or value, besides Oblations, Offerings, Sprinkle-ing money and the like, with Severall other petty customes fees and perquisites; Yet what a continuall flattering croaking and craveing they allwayes kept to the severall powers formerly in being, for Augmentations, Stipenes and Additions, &c. Amongst the number of which clamorouse Pentioners, I never heard the voice of one contented Hezekiah, so much as once to say we have enough, 2, Chron: 81, 10. vers,
But rather like the daughter of the Horse-leech still crying Give, give, Prov. 30.15. or like the Grave, the Barren wombe or thirsty Earth, allwayes swallowing & never saying it is enough.

Moreover I finde that tything of Corne and Graine by Gods CÅmand (as to the materiall and substantiall part thereof) was limitted and related only to increase, And as to the practick part (relateing to the manner and forme) it was to be done in seed as may more at large appeare by the Command it selfe, Deut: 14.12. vers, Thou shalt truly tith all the Increase of thy Seed which the feild bringeth forth yeare by yeare &c. From whence these naturall inferrences doe arise, First that the husbandman himselfe must tyth his Corne, Secondly he must tyth in Seed and not in Shease. Thirdly he must only tyth the Increase of his seed Fourthly He must truly tyth all the Increase (that is) he must take the exact tenth part of the Increase, and neither less nor more. And fifthly if there were noe Increase noe tyth was due or payable.

But the Clergie of this Generation minding more there owne gaine then Gods Command enforce the Countryman to tyth his Corne in Sheafe and not in seed, whereby they take as well a tenth part of the Farmers Stock and substance as a tenth of his Increase, Nay more for though the Farmer somtimes ãâã
Reape halfe the vallue of what he Sowed, the Parish Preist will have a tenth of what he Reapeth, whereby a most Insensible and vnsufferrable mischiefe doth ensue. And therefore haveing very breifly, and truly opened the afore mentioned Text of Scriptures, I shall endeavour In Love and Pitty to the wronged Countryman. In a vse of Information to Applie it.

In order then to the more perfect vnderstanding of his proper Interest, the Husbandman that thinks he is bound to pay his tyth by Gods Command, must needes (if he be wise) observe this Rule, Allwayes to put a differrence betweene his Reall Stock, & Reall profitt, betweene the Principall and the product or Increase els by confounding both together he knows not how he getts or how he looses, As thus (for instance) if the Husbandman doe Sowe Tenn barrells of Wheat at seed tyme, which is worth Tenn poundes; he must remember that his principall Stocke and Substance is tenn poundes less in value by what he hath cast into the ground, And when the harvest Comes, he must also minde to thresh out so much wheat, as the full Quantity of what he Sowed, that so his Stock may be Reprized and made good againe, and haveing thus donn That which remaines of Over-plus is cleare Increase, and out of the Increase of Seed was tyth by Gods apointment to be paid, as I have shewed before,

But by the Clergies forceing men to tyth in Sheafe against the order of Gods Command for tything a most Insufferable Inconveniency doth ensue (as I have said) for by this meanes the Clergie do not only take a yearly tenth of mens Increase but of theire principall Stock and Substance also; whereby the substance of the husbandman becomes lyable to a perpetuall Consumation by Decrimation; so that by vndeniable Instances it may be made appeare That if a Farmer Imploy a hundred poundes in Tillage and pursue the same for seaven yeares together, at seaven yeares end the Parish-Preist to whom he payes his tyth in Sheafe, will have above Fiftie poundes of the Farmers principall Stock into his hands by Tything. Besides the full tenth part of his Increase.

And hence it is that many an able Farmer comes to want, & poverty over-takes him as an armed man, and he knowes not who hath hurt him, But somtimes blames his Landlord and thinkes he hath too hard a bargaine; or otherwise faults his Servants, and the like, but thinkes not of his Master who suckes away his Substance most insensably, and makes him pay so deare a Rate to feede his Soule, That he hath nothing left to feede his body.
